Currently, this occurs only in some [[Apostasy in Islam|Muslim-majority]] countries and Muslim-majority states in Northern [[Nigeria]].<ref name= Indy1 >{{cite web |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/the-13-countries-where-being-an-atheist-is-punishable-by-death-a6960561.html |title= The 13 countries where being an atheist is punishable by death |date= 30 March 2016 |first1= Siobhan |last1= Fenton |publisher= [[The Independent]] |accessdate= 23 November 2016}}</ref><ref name="reuters131210"/><ref name= "iheu report"/><ref name= FreethoughtReport>{{cite web |url= http://freethoughtreport.com/download-the-report/ |title= The Freedom of Thought Report |date= 2015 |publisher= [[International Humanist and Ethical Union]] |accessdate = 20 November 2016}}</ref>]] {{Status of religious freedom |persecution}} {{Irreligion sidebar|atheism}} {{Atheism sidebar|people}} {{Discrimination sidebar|Social}} '''Discrimination against atheists''', both at present and historically, includes [[Religious persecution|persecution]] of and [[Religious discrimination|discrimination]] against people identified as [[atheist]]s, whether by themselves or by others. Discrimination against atheists may also comprise negative attitudes, prejudice, hostility, hatred, fear, or intolerance towards atheists and atheism. Because atheism can be defined in various ways, those discriminated against or persecuted on the grounds of being atheists might not have been considered atheists in a different time or place. 13 Muslim countries officially punish atheism or apostasy by death, while "the overwhelming majority" of the 192 United Nation member countries "at best discriminate against citizens who have no belief in a god and at worst can jail them for offences dubbed blasphemy".<ref name="reuters131210"/>
In some [[Muslim world|Muslim-majority countries]], atheists face persecution and severe penalties such as the withdrawal of [[Status (law)|legal status]] or, in the case of [[Apostasy in Islam|apostasy]], [[Capital punishment#Islam|capital punishment]].<ref name="Jakarta Globe">{{cite web | title = ‘God Does Not Exist’ Comment Ends Badly for Indonesia Man | url = http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/news/god-does-not-exist-comment-ends-badly-for-indonesia-man/492370 | accessdate = 2012-01-20}}</ref>
==Other names== Sometimes such discrimination is called '''atheophobia''',<ref>{{cite book |first=Barney |last=Warf |year=2015 |chapter=Atheist Geographies and Geographies of Atheism |chapterurl=https://www.amazon.com/Changing-World-Religion-Map-Identities/dp/9401793751/ref=mt_hardcover?_encoding=UTF8&me=#reader_9401793751 |title=The Changing World Religion Map |editor1=Stanley D. Brunn |editor2=Donna A. Gilbreath |volume=4 |page=2225 |isbn=978-94-017-9375-9 |accessdate=February 13, 2017 |via=Amazon.com |quote=[...] to openly discriminate against them [atheists], or practice atheophobia.}}</ref> '''atheistophobia''',<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bomi2eh7xocC&lpg=PA293&dq=atheistophobia&pg=PA291#v=onepage&q=atheistophobia&f=false|title=Rhetoric and Argumentation in the Beginning of the XX Century|last=Ribeiro|first=Henrique Jales|date=2009-12-01|publisher=Imprensa da Universidade de Coimbra / Coimbra University Press|isbn=9789898074775|language=en}}</ref> '''anti-atheist discrimination''',<ref>{{cite book |first1=Ryan T. |last1=Cragun |author2=Joseph H. Hammer |author3=Jesse M. Smith |year=2013 |chapter=North America |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=jbIVAgAAQBAJ&lpg=PA617&dq=anti-atheism%20discrimination&pg=PA615#v=onepage&q=anti-atheism%20discrimination&f=false |title=The Oxford Handbook of Atheism |editor1=Stephen Bullivant |editor2=Michael Ruse |publisher=Oxford University Press |pages=xiii, 615+ |accessdate=February 13, 2017 |via=Google Books }}</ref> or '''anti-atheist sentiment'''.
==Ancient times== Scholars have argued that some small underdeveloped glimpses of atheism existed in the [[Ancient history|ancient world]], though not in a modern sense because people had not developed a language for nonbelief; [[Theism|theistic]] beliefs in 5th Century BC Greece were not very active in public life the way they are in the modern world, and [[polytheism]] made it difficult to centralize the beliefs of any region or culture.<ref name="whitmarsh">{{cite book|last=Whitmarsh|first=Tim|title=Battling the Gods: Atheism in the Ancient World|publisher=Knopf|year=2015|isbn=978-0-307-95833-4}}</ref> [[Lucien Febvre]] has referred to the "unthinkability" of atheism in its strongest sense before the sixteenth century, because of the "deep religiosity" of that era. [[Karen Armstrong]] has concurred, writing "from birth and baptism to death and burial in the churchyard, religion dominated the life of every single man and woman. Every activity of the day, which was punctuated by church bells summoning the faithful to prayer, was saturated with religious beliefs and institutions: they dominated professional and public life—even the guilds and the universities were religious organizations. ... Even if an exceptional man could have achieved the objectivity necessary to question the nature of religion and the existence of God, he would have found no support in either the philosophy or the science of his time."<ref name="davidson">{{cite book|last=Davidson|first=Nicholas|title=Atheism from the Reformation to the Enlightenment|editor=Michael Hunter; David Wootton|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1992|pages=55–86|chapter=Unbelief and Atheism In Italy|isbn=978-0-19-822736-6}}</ref><ref name="books.google">{{cite book|last=Armstrong |first=Karen |title=A History of God: The 4000-year Quest of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam |publisher=Random House, Inc. |pages=286–87|year=1994|url= https://books.google.com/?id=_n3cCF2I2FUC&printsec=frontcover&dq=A+History+of+God| isbn=978-0-345-38456-0}}</ref><ref name="kelley">{{cite book|last=Kelley|first=Donald R. |title=Frontiers of History: Historical Inquiry in the Twentieth Century |publisher=Yale University Press|year=2006|page=115|isbn=978-0-300-12062-2|url=https://books.google.com/?id=K-wVctit5U8C&pg=PA115}}</ref> As governmental authority rested on the notion of [[Divine right of kings|divine right]], it was threatened by those who denied the existence of the local god. Those labeled as atheist, including early Christians and Muslims, were as a result targeted for legal persecution.<ref name="gey 250">{{cite book|last=Gey|first=Steven G.|title=The Cambridge Companion to Atheism|editor=Martin, Michael|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2007|chapter=Atheism and the Freedom of Religion|pages=250–253, 260–2 |isbn=978-0-521-84270-9|url=https://books.google.com/?id=tAeFipOVx4MC&pg=PA250}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Armstrong |first=Karen |title=A History of God: The 4000-year Quest of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam |publisher=Random House, Inc. |pages=98, 147|year=1994|url= https://books.google.com/?id=_n3cCF2I2FUC&printsec=frontcover|isbn=978-0-345-38456-0}}</ref>
==Early modern period and Reformation== {{Further|Atheism in the Age of Enlightenment}} During the [[early modern period]], the term "atheist" was used as an insult and applied to a broad range of people, including those who held opposing theological beliefs, as well as those who had committed [[suicide]], immoral or self-indulgent people, and even opponents of the belief in witchcraft.<ref name="davidson"/><ref name="books.google"/><ref name="laursen">{{cite book|last=Laursen|first=John Christian |author2=Nederman, Cary J.|title=Beyond the Persecuting Society: Religious Toleration Before the Enlightenment |publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|year=1997|page=142|isbn= 978-0-8122-1567-0|url=https://books.google.com/?id=r2j6ZHgXZWkC&pg=PA142}}</ref> Atheistic beliefs were seen as threatening to order and society by philosophers such as [[Thomas Aquinas]]. Lawyer and scholar [[Thomas More]] said that religious tolerance should be extended to all except those who did not believe in a deity or the immortality of the soul.<ref name="gey 250"/> [[John Locke]], a founder of modern notions of religious liberty, argued that atheists (as well as Catholics and Muslims) should not be granted full citizenship rights.<ref name="gey 250"/>
During the [[Inquisition]], several of those accused of atheism or blasphemy, or both, were tortured or executed. These included the priest [[Giulio Cesare Vanini]] who was strangled and burned in 1619 and the Polish nobleman [[Kazimierz Łyszczyński]] who was executed in Warsaw,<ref name="davidson"/><ref name="brooke">{{cite book|last= Brooke|first=John Hedley|others= Maclean, Ian |title=Heterodoxy in Early Modern Science and Religion |publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2005|isbn=978-0-19-926897-9|url=https://books.google.com/?id=W9o_OEvMQTcC&pg=PA66}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Kłoczowski |first=Jerzy |title=A History of Polish Christianity |publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2000 |page=155|isbn=978-0-521-36429-4|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ecdye8hk_tgC&pg=PA155}}</ref> as well as [[Etienne Dolet]], a Frenchman executed in 1546. Though heralded as atheist martyrs during the nineteenth century, recent scholars hold that the beliefs espoused by Dolet and Vanini are not atheistic in modern terms.<ref name="kelley"/><ref name="onfray">{{cite book|last=Onfray|first=Michel|others=Leggatt, Jeremy (translator) |title=Atheist manifesto: the case against Christianity, Judaism, and Islam |publisher=Arcade Publishing|year=2007|page=24|isbn=978-1-55970-820-3|url=https://books.google.com/?id=QpEAYMo7pFkC&pg=PA24}}</ref><ref name="chadwich">{{cite book|last=Chadwick |first=Owen |title=The Early Reformation on the Continent By |publisher= Oxford University Press|year=2003|isbn=978-0-19-926578-7|url=https://books.google.com/?id=VR1yNW8mgoEC&pg=PA413}}</ref>
== Modern era == === Victorian Britain === {{Further information|Irreligion in the United Kingdom}} During the nineteenth century, British atheists, though few in number, were subject to discriminatory practices.<ref name="cookson">{{cite book | author = Larson, Timothy| chapter= Victorian England | title = Encyclopedia of religious freedom | editor= Cookson, Catharine| publisher = Routledge | location = New York | year = 2003 | isbn = 0-415-94181-4 | oclc = }}</ref> The poet [[Percy Bysshe Shelley]] was expelled from the University of Oxford and denied custody of his two children after publishing a pamphlet titled ''[[The Necessity of Atheism]]''.<ref name="gey253" /> Those unwilling to swear Christian oaths during judicial proceedings were unable to give evidence in court to obtain justice until this requirement was repealed by Acts passed in 1869 and 1870.<ref name="cookson"/>
Atheist [[Charles Bradlaugh]] was elected as a [[Member of Parliament (UK)|Member of the British Parliament]] in 1880. He was denied the right to affirm rather than swear his oath of office, and was then denied the ability to swear the oath as other Members objected that he had himself said it would be meaningless. Bradlaugh was re-elected three times before he was finally able to take his seat in 1886 when the Speaker of the House permitted him to take the oath.<ref name="gey253">{{cite book|last=Gey|first=Steven G.|title=The Cambridge Companion to Atheism|editor=Martin, Michael|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2007|chapter=Atheism and the Freedom of Religion|pages=253–255|isbn=978-0-521-84270-9|url=https://books.google.com/?id=tAeFipOVx4MC&pg=PA253}}</ref>
=== Nazi Germany === {{Further information|Irreligion in Nazi Germany}} In Germany during the Nazi era, a 1933 decree stated that "No National Socialist may suffer detriment... on the ground that he does not make any religious profession at all".<ref name="Baynes"/> However, the regime strongly opposed "godless communism",<ref>{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Christian|title=Disruptive religion: the force of faith in social-movement activism|publisher=Routledge|year=1996|pages=156–57|isbn=978-0-415-91405-5|url=https://books.google.com/?id=39SoSG4NGAoC&pg=PA156}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Stackelberg|first=Roderick|title=The Routledge Companion to Nazi Germany|publisher=Routledge|year=2007|pages=136–8|isbn=978-0-415-30860-1|url=https://books.google.com/?id=cpXIR9yOMuoC&pg=PA136}}</ref> and all of Germany's atheist and largely left-wing [[freethought]] organizations such as the [[German Freethinkers League]] (500,000 members)<ref name="NYT">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1933/05/14/archives/atheist-hall-converted-berlin-churches-establish-bureau-to-win-back.html |title=Atheist Hall Converted: Berlin Churches Establish Bureau to Win Back Worshipers |work=The New York Times |date=May 14, 1933 |page=2 |accessdate=September 18, 2010}}</ref> were banned the same year; some right-wing groups were tolerated by the Nazis until the mid-1930s.<ref name="may">{{cite book |last= Bock| first= Heike | chapter= Secularization of the modern conduct of life? Reflections on the religiousness of early modern Europe| editor=Hanne May |title=Religiosität in der säkularisierten Welt |publisher=VS Verlag fnr Sozialw |year=2006 |page= 157|isbn=3-8100-4039-8 |oclc= |url= https://books.google.com/?id=nfQ0pqA53Z8C&pg=PA157}}</ref><ref name=kaiser>{{cite book|last=Kaiser|first=Jochen-Christoph|title=Atheismus und religiöse Indifferenz|editor=Christel Gärtner|publisher=VS Verlag|year=2003|volume=Organisierter Atheismus|pages= 122, 124–6|isbn=978-3-8100-3639-1|url=https://books.google.com/?id=YXOr4xQFSJsC&pg=PA124}}</ref> In a speech made later in 1933, Hitler claimed to have "stamped out" the atheistic movement.<ref name="Baynes">{{cite book|last=Baynes|first=Norman Hepburn|title=The Speeches of Adolf Hitler, April 1922 – August 1939'|publisher=H. Fertig|year=1969|page=378|quote= Without pledging ourselves to any particular Confession, we have restored faith to its pre-requisites because we were convinced that the people needs [sic] and requires [sic] this faith. We have therefore undertaken the fight against the atheistic movement [Gottlosenbewegung], and that not merely with a few theoretical declarations: we have stamped it out.}}</ref>
During the negotiations leading up to the Nazi-Vatican Concordat of April 26, 1933 Hitler stated that "Secular schools can never be tolerated" because of their irreligious tendencies.<ref>Ernst Helmreich, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=I6DYAAAAMAAJ The German Churches Under Hitler]''. Detroit: Wayne State Univ. Press, 1979, p. 241.</ref> Hitler routinely disregarded this undertaking, and the [[Reich concordat]] as a whole and by 1939, all Catholic denominational schools had been disbanded or converted to public facilities.<ref>Evans, Richard J. (2005). The Third Reich in Power. New York: Penguin. {{ISBN|978-0-14-303790-3}}; pp. 245-246</ref>
By 1939, 94.5% of Germans still called themselves Protestant or Catholic, while 3.5% were so-called "''[[Gottgläubig]]en''" (lit. "believers in God") and 1.5% were without faith.<ref name="Ziegler">{{Cite book |last=Ziegler |first=Herbert F. |date=2014 |title=Nazi Germany's New Aristocracy: The SS Leadership, 1925-1939 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kBgABAAAQBAJ&pg=PA86 |location=Princeton, New Jersey |publisher=Princeton University Press |pages=85–87 |isbn=9781400860364 |accessdate=23 January 2018}}</ref> According to historian [[Richard J. Evans]], those members of the affiliation ''gottgläubig'' "were convinced Nazis who had left their Church at the behest of the Party, which had been trying since the mid-1930s to reduce the influence of Christianity in society".<ref>[[Richard J. Evans]]; ''The Third Reich at War''; Penguin Press; New York 2009, p. 546</ref> [[Heinrich Himmler]] was a strong promoter of the ''gottgläubig'' movement and didn't allow atheists into the [[SS]], arguing that their "refusal to acknowledge higher powers" would be a "potential source of indiscipline".<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=l5gcZpnL5QUC&pg=PA196&dq=gottglaubig&hl=en&sa=X&ei=RVtlU-L_HNGe7AbJ64DoBg&ved=0CE8Q6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q=gottglaubig&f=false|title=The Third Reich|publisher=|accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> Himmler announced to the [[Schutzstaffel|SS]]: "We believe in a God Almighty who stands above us; he has created the earth, the Fatherland, and the Volk, and he has sent us the Führer. Any human being who does not believe in God should be considered arrogant, megalomaniacal, and stupid and thus not suited for the SS."<ref name="Ziegler"/>
==Contemporary era==
===Human rights=== {{main|History of human rights}} Article 18 of the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] is designed to protect the right to freedom of thought, conscience, and religion. In 1993, the UN's human rights committee declared that article 18 of the [[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]] "protects theistic, non-theistic and atheistic beliefs, as well as the right not to profess any religion or belief".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.minorityrights.org/3273/normative-instruments/ccpr-general-comment-22-300793-on-iccpr-article-18.html|title=CCPR General Comment 22: 30/07/93 on ICCPR Article 18|work=Minorityrights.org|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150116043952/http://www.minorityrights.org/3273/normative-instruments/ccpr-general-comment-22-300793-on-iccpr-article-18.html|archivedate=16 January 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The committee further stated that "the freedom to have or to adopt a religion or belief necessarily entails the freedom to choose a religion or belief, including the right to replace one's current religion or belief with another or to adopt atheistic views". Signatories to the convention are barred from "the use of threat of physical force or penal sanctions to compel believers or non-believers" to recant their beliefs or convert. Despite this, atheists still are persecuted in some parts of the world.<ref name="fdih1">{{cite web |date=1 August 2003|title=Discrimination against religious minorities in Iran|author=International Federation for Human Rights|publisher=fdih.org|accessdate=3 March 2009|url=http://www.fidh.org/IMG/pdf/ir0108a.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.law2.byu.edu/lawreview/archives/2002/2/dav2.pdf|title=The Evolution of Religious Liberty as a Universal Human Right|accessdate=3 March 2009|last=Davis|first=Derek H.|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723210828/http://www.law2.byu.edu/lawreview/archives/2002/2/dav2.pdf|archive-date=23 July 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Western countries=== Modern theories of [[constitutional democracy]] assume that citizens are intellectually and spiritually autonomous and that governments should leave matters of religious belief to individuals and not coerce religious beliefs using sanctions or benefits. The constitutions, human rights conventions and the religious liberty jurisprudence of most constitutional democracies provide legal protection of atheists and agnostics. In addition, freedom of expression provisions and legislation separating church from state also serve to protect the rights of atheists. As a result, open legal discrimination against atheists is not common in most Western countries.<ref name="gey 250" /> However, prejudice against atheists does exist in Western countries. A [[UBC|University of British Columbia]] study conducted in the United States found that believers distrusted atheists as much they did [[rapists]]. The study also showed that atheists had lower employment prospects.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www2.psych.ubc.ca/~ara/Manuscripts/Gervais%20et%20al-%20Atheist%20Distrust.pdf|title=Do You Believe in Atheists? Distrust Is Central to Anti-Atheist Prejudice|first1=Will M.|last1=Gervais|first2=Azim F.|last2=Shariff|first3=Ara|last3=Norenzayan|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|year=2011|volume=101|issue=6|pages=1189–1206|accessdate=April 22, 2012|doi=10.1037/a0025882|pmid=22059841}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/religion/story/2011-12-10/religion-atheism/51777612/1|title=Study: Atheists distrusted as much as rapists|work=usatoday.com}}</ref>
====Europe==== {{Further information|Irreligion in Europe}} In most of Europe, atheists are elected to office at high levels in many governments without controversy.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ibka.org/en/articles/miz08/politics-religion-usa|title="Most American secularists have few expectations..." An Interview with AAI president Stuart Bechman|last=Hartmann|first=René|date=March 2008|work=MIZ Magazine|accessdate=2009-03-14}}</ref> Some atheist organizations in Europe have expressed concerns regarding issues of separation of church and state, such as administrative fees for leaving the Church charged in Germany,<ref> {{cite web |url=http://ibka.org/en/fee-european-court |title=Fee for leaving church is brought before European Court of Human Rights | I |publisher=International League of Non-religious and Atheists (IBKA) |accessdate=2009-03-14}} </ref> and sermons being organized by the Swedish parliament.<ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.jo.se/Page.aspx?MenuId=106&MainMenuId=106&Language=sv&ObjectClass=DynamX_SFS_Decision&Id=2100 |title = Anmälan till JO – Riksdagens ombudsmän |publisher = jo.se |accessdate = 2009-03-14 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071122134930/http://www.jo.se/Page.aspx?MenuId=106&MainMenuId=106&Language=sv&ObjectClass=DynamX_SFS_Decision&Id=2100 |archivedate = 22 November 2007 |df = dmy-all }} </ref> Ireland requires religious training from Christian colleges in order to work as a teacher in government-funded schools.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/opinion/2010/0202/1224263575172.html |title=Why must agnostics be obliged to teach faith? |work=The Irish Times |accessdate=2010-02-02 |date=2 February 2010}}</ref> In the UK one-third of state-funded schools are faith-based.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.runnymedetrust.org/uploads/publications/Summaries/RightToDivide-Summary.pdf|title=Right to Divide? Faith Schools and Community Cohesion|last=Berkeley|first=Rob|author2=Savita Vij|date=December 2008|publisher=[[Runnymede Trust]]|page=4|accessdate=7 December 2011|location=London}}</ref> However, there are no restrictions on atheists holding public office – the former [[Deputy Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]], [[Nick Clegg]], is an atheist.<ref>{{cite news|last=Peev |first=Gerri |url=http://news.scotsman.com/politics/I-don39t-believe-in-God.3607087.jp |title=Religion: I don't believe in God |work=The Scotsman |date= 20 December 2007|accessdate=14 April 2010 |location=Edinburgh}}</ref> According to a 2012 poll, 25% of the [[Turks in Germany]] believe atheists are inferior human beings.<ref>Liljeberg Research International: [https://d171.keyingress.de/multimedia/document/228.pdf ''Deutsch-Türkische Lebens und Wertewelten 2012''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011112234/https://d171.keyingress.de/multimedia/document/228.pdf |date=11 October 2012 }}, July/August 2012, p. 68</ref><ref>[[Die Welt]]: [https://www.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article108659406/Tuerkische-Migranten-hoffen-auf-muslimische-Mehrheit.html ''Türkische Migranten hoffen auf muslimische Mehrheit''], 17 August 2012, retrieved 23 August 2012</ref> Portugal has elected two presidents, [[Mário Soares]], who was also elected Prime-Minister, and [[Jorge Sampaio]], who have openly expressed their irreligion, as well as two agnostic Prime-Ministers, [[José Sócrates]] and [[António Costa]]. On the contrary, in Greece, the right-wing New Democracy government stated that "the Greek people have a right to know whether Mr. [[Alexis Tsipras|Tsipras]] is an atheist", citing their political opponent's irreligiosity as a reason he should not be elected, even though they granted that "it is his right".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skai.gr/news/politics/article/250179/nd-o-ellinikos-prepei-na-gnorizei-an-o-tsipras-einai-atheosd/|title=ΝΔ: Ο ελληνικός λαός πρέπει να γνωρίζει αν ο Τσίπρας είναι άθεος - η απάντηση ΣΥΡΙΖΑ|work=skai.gr}}</ref> In the [[Elder Pastitsios]] case, a 27-year-old was sentenced to imprisonment for satirizing a popular apocalyptically-minded Greek Orthodox monk, while several [[Metropolitan bishop|metropolitans]] of the Greek Orthodox Church (which is not separated from the state) have also urged their flock "not to vote unbelievers into office", even going so far as to warn Greek Orthodox laymen that they would be "sinning if they voted atheists into public office".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pentapostagma.gr/2014/05/%CE%BC%CE%B5%CF%83%CE%BF%CE%B3%CE%B1%CE%AF%CE%B1%CF%82-%CE%BD%CE%B9%CE%BA%CF%8C%CE%BB%CE%B1%CE%BF%CF%82-%CE%B1%CE%BC%CE%B1%CF%81%CF%84%CE%AF%CE%B1-%CE%B1%CE%BD-%CE%B4%CF%8E%CF%83%CE%BF%CF%85.html|title=Μεσογαίας Νικόλαος: "Αμαρτία αν δώσουμε ψήφο σε ανθρώπους χωρίς πίστη, αξίες και σεβασμό στην ιστορία"|work=Pentapostagma.gr|accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.topontiki.gr/article/65820|title=Μητροπολίτης Γόρτυνος: "Το ράσο μου πετάει τριφασικό ρεύμα" (Video)|publisher=|accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref>
====Brazil==== {{Further|Irreligion in Brazil}} A 2009 survey showed that atheists were the most hated demographic group in Brazil, among several other minorities polled, being almost on par with drug addicts. According to the research, 17% of the interviewees stated they felt either hatred or repulsion for atheists, while 25% felt antipathy and 29% were indifferent.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.paulopes.com.br/2009/05/ateus-e-usuarios-de-drogas-sao-os-mais.html|title=Ateus e drogados são os mais odiados pelos brasileiros|work=Paulopes.com.br|date=May 3, 2009|accessdate=August 4, 2013|language=Portuguese}}</ref>
====Canada==== {{Further|Irreligion in Canada}} Canadian [[secular humanist]] groups have worked to end the recitation of prayers during government proceedings, viewing them as discriminatory.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.humanistcanada.com/no-prayers-in-ont-legislature |title=No More Prayers in Legislature |publisher=humanistcanada.com |accessdate=2009-03-14 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090904171238/http://www.humanistcanada.com/no-prayers-in-ont-legislature/ |archivedate=2009-09-04 |deadurl=yes }} </ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/article/423192|title=Stirring up yet another religious storm|last=Hurst|first=Lynda|date= 9 May 2008 |work=Toronto Star|accessdate=2009-03-14}}</ref> [[Scouts Canada]] states that while a belief in God or affiliation with organized religion is not a requirement to join, members must have "a basic spiritual belief"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scouts.ca/ca/frequently-asked-questions|title=Frequently Asked Questions|publisher=|accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> and one of the core values is "Duty to God: Defined as, The responsibility to adhere to spiritual principles, and thus to the religion that expresses them, and to accept the duties therefrom."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scouts.ca/ca/values|title=Values|publisher=|accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref>

In the United States, [[#seven|seven state constitutions]] include religious tests that would effectively prevent atheists from holding public office, and in some cases being a juror/witness, though these have not generally been enforced since the early twentieth century.<ref name="acl" /><ref>{{cite book|last=Giacalone|first=Robert A|author2=Jurkiewicz, Carole L. |title=Handbook of Workplace Spirituality and Organizational Performance |publisher=M.E. Several American atheists have used court challenges to address discrimination against atheists. [[Michael Newdow]] challenged inclusion of the phrase "under God" in the United States [[Pledge of Allegiance (United States)|Pledge of Allegiance]] on behalf of his daughter, claiming that the phrase amounted to government endorsement of discrimination against atheists.<ref name="bishop">{{cite book|last=Bishop|first=Ronald|title=Taking on the Pledge of Allegiance: The News Media and Michael Newdow's Constitutional Challenge |publisher=SUNY Press|year=2007|pages=39–40|isbn=978-0-7914-7181-4|url=https://books.google.com/?id=T6v-hpqD654C&pg=PA39}}</ref> He won the case at an initial stage, but the Supreme Court dismissed his claim, ruling that Newdow did not have [[standing (law)|standing]] to bring his case, thus disposing of the case without ruling on the constitutionality of the pledge.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/low/americas/3806181.stm|title=US to keep 'under God' pledge|date=14 June 2004|work=BBC News |accessdate=2009-03-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-8128948_ITM|title=U.S. Supreme Court Dismisses Pledge Challenge|last=Mintz|first=Howard|date=15 June 2004|work= San Jose Mercury News |accessdate=2009-03-13}}</ref> Respondents to a survey were less likely to support a kidney transplant for hypothetical atheists and agnostics needing it, than for Christian patients with similar medical needs.<ref>[http://www.pitzer.edu/academics/faculty/zuckerman/Zuckerman_on_Atheism.pdf Atheism, Secularity, and Well-Being: How the Findings of Social Science Counter Negative Stereotypes and Assumptions, Phil Zuckerman*] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141228104545/http://www.pitzer.edu/academics/faculty/zuckerman/Zuckerman_on_Atheism.pdf |date=28 December 2014 }}</ref> As the [[Boy Scouts of America]] [[Boy Scouts of America membership controversies#Position on religious belief|does not allow atheists as members]], atheist families and the [[American Civil Liberties Union|ACLU]] from the 1990s onwards have launched a series of court cases arguing discrimination against atheists. In response to ACLU lawsuits, the Pentagon in 2004 ended sponsorship of [[Scouting]] units,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aclu-il.org/legal/courtdocuments/2004/11/winkler_v_chicago_school_refor.shtml|year=2004|title=Winkler v. Chicago School Reform Board|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120607215939/http://www.aclu-il.org/legal/courtdocuments/2004/11/winkler_v_chicago_school_refor.shtml|archivedate=2012-06-07|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usdoj.gov/opa/pr/2004/November/04_civ_751.htm |title=Department of Defense settles part of litigation challenging its involvement with the Boy Scouts of America |publisher=Usdoj.gov |date=16 November 2004 |accessdate=4 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090508175203/http://www.usdoj.gov/opa/pr/2004/November/04_civ_751.htm |archivedate=8 May 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref> and in 2005 the BSA agreed to transfer all Scouting units out of government entities such as public schools.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aclu-il.org/news/press/2005/03/national_boy_scout_organizatio.shtml|work=American Civil Liberties Union of Illinois|title=National Boy Scout Organization Agrees to End All Local Government Direct Sponsorship of Troops and Packs|accessdate=2006-03-02|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121085949/http://www.aclu-il.org/news/press/2005/03/national_boy_scout_organizatio.shtml|archivedate=2008-11-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/metro/20041116-115229-4427r.htm|work=Washington Times|title=Boy Scouts Jamboree to Stay at Army Base|accessdate=2006-03-02|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060419175333/http://www.washingtontimes.com/metro/20041116-115229-4427r.htm|archivedate=2006-04-19}}</ref>
Despite polling showing that nonbelievers make up an increasingly large part of the population there is only one public atheist in all of the state legislatures across the nation. Few politicians have been willing to acknowledge their lack of belief in supreme beings, since such revelations have been considered "political suicide".<ref name="SFC">{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2007/03/14/MNG7BOKV111.DTL |title=Stark's atheist views break political taboo|last=Marinucci|first=Carla|work=San Francisco Chronicle|accessdate=2009-03-12 | date=2007-03-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nysun.com/national/california-lawmaker-becomes-highest-ranking/50312/ |title=California Lawmaker Becomes Highest-Ranking Official To Say He's a Nonbeliever |publisher=Nysun.com |accessdate=4 December 2011}}</ref> On September 20, 2007, Pete Stark became the first nontheist United States congressman to openly acknowledge a lack of belief, joining the millions of Americans whom have long kept their views secret for fear of discrimination in their communities.<ref name="AHA"/> There is one state legislator, [[Ernie Chambers]], currently holding a seat in the [[Nebraska Legislature|Nebraska State Legislature]]. [[Cecil Bothwell]], who has publicly stated he doesn't believe in gods and that it's "certainly not relevant to public office", was elected on November 3, 2009, to the Asheville, North Carolina city council after he won the third highest number of votes in the city election. Following the election, political opponents of Bothwell threatened to challenge his election on the grounds that the North Carolina Constitution does not allow for atheists to hold public office in the state. However, that provision, dating back to 1868, is unenforceable and invalid because the United States Constitution prevents religious tests for public office.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/12/14/critics-say-atheist-nc-city-councilman-unworthy-seat/ |title=Critics Say Atheist N.C. City councilman Unworthy of Seat |publisher=Fox News |date=7 April 2010 |accessdate=4 December 2011}}</ref> A 2015 Gallup survey found that 40% of Americans would not vote an atheist for president,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/183713/socialist-presidential-candidates-least-appealing.aspx|title=In U.S., Socialist Presidential Candidates Least Appealing|date=22 June 2015|publisher=Gallup|access-date=2 March 2017}}</ref> and in polls prior to 2015, that number had reached about 50%.<ref>{{cite journal | url = https://www.motherjones.com/news/exhibit/2004/09/09_200.html | title = Faith in the System | journal = [[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] |date=September–October 2004 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2007-03-11-politics-diversity-cover_N.htm|title=2008 race has the face of a changing America|last=Page|first=Susan|work=USA Today|accessdate=2009-03-13 | date=2007-03-12}}</ref> A 2014 study by the University of Minnesota found that 42% of respondents characterized atheists as a group that did "not at all agree with my vision of American society", and that 44% would not want their child to marry an atheist. The negative attitudes towards atheists were higher than negative attitudes towards African-Americans and homosexuals but lower than the negative attitudes towards Muslims.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Gerteis |first1=Joseph |last2=Stewart |first2=Evan |last3=Hartmann |first3=Douglas |last4=Edgell |first4=Penny |date=7 November 2016 |title=Atheists and Other Cultural Outsiders: Moral Boundaries and the Non-Religious in the United States |journal=University of Minnesota |volume=95 |issue=2 |page=619 |id= |url=https://academic.oup.com/sf/article-pdf/95/2/607/9597834/sow063.pdf |quote= |doi=}}</ref> Many in the U.S. associate atheism with [[immorality]], including criminal behaviour, extreme materialism, communism and [[elitism]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.authentichistory.com/1946-1960/4-cwhomefront/7-comics/tcgodless/This_Godless_Communism_1961.html|title=This Godless Communism, 1961|publisher=authentichistory.com}}</ref> The studies also showed that rejection of atheists was related to the respondent's lack of exposure to diversity, education and political orientations.<ref name="UMN News">{{cite web |url=http://www1.umn.edu/news/news-releases/2006/UR_RELEASE_MIG_2816.html |title=Atheists identified as America's most distrusted minority, according to new U of M study |publisher=UMN News |accessdate=2006-03-22}}</ref> Atheists and atheist organizations have alleged discrimination against atheists in the military,<ref>{{YouTube|P7d2rpN4cc4|(2009). Mandatory Prayer in the Army}}. Retrieved on November 28, 2010{{dead link|date=December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.militaryatheists.org/ |title=MAAF (2009). Military Association of Atheists & Freethinkers. Retrieved November 28, 2010 from http |publisher=militaryatheists.org|date=27 April 2011 |accessdate=4 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.armytimes.com/news/2008/09/airforce_lakenheath_suit_093008/ |author=LaGrone, S.|date=September 30, 2008|title=Soldier alleges religious bias at Lakenheath|publisher=Armytimes.com |accessdate=4 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.militaryreligiousfreedom.com|title=MILITARYRELIGIOUSFREEDOM.COM|publisher=|accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/11/02/air-force-academy-cites-p_n_777937.html |author1=Jones, W. |title=Air Force Academy Cites Progress In Tackling Religious Intolerance|work=Huffington Post |date=28 September 2010 |accessdate=4 December 2011 |editor=Fleet, Josh}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.militaryatheists.org/rptchap.html |title=Military Association of Atheists and Freethinkers Report on chaplains|publisher=militaryatheists.org|accessdate=4 December 2011}}</ref> and recently, with the development of the [[Comprehensive Soldier and Family Fitness|Army's Comprehensive Soldier Fitness program]], atheists have alleged [[institutionalized discrimination]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/01/06/army-faces-questions-over_n_805524.html|author= Banks, Adelle|title= Army Faces Questions Over 'Spiritual Fitness' Test|work=Huffington Post |date=16 January 2011 |accessdate=4 December 2011 |editor=Fleet, Josh}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.militaryreligiousfreedom.org/docs/spirituality_testing_cnd.pdf |work=MAAF|date=December 30, 2010|title=The Comprehensive Soldier Fitness Program's Unconstitutional Soldier Fitness Tracker and Global Assessment Tool |format=PDF |accessdate=4 December 2011}}</ref> In several [[child custody]] court rulings, atheist parents have been discriminated against, either directly or indirectly. As [[child custody laws in the United States]] are often based on the subjective opinion of family court judges, atheism has frequently been used to deny custody to non-religious parents on the basis that a parent's lack of faith displays a lack of morality required to raise a child.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www2.law.ucla.edu/volokh/custody.pdf|year=2006|format=PDF|title=Parent-child speech and child custody speech restrictions|first=Eugene|last=Volokh|journal=New York University Law Review|volume=81|page=631}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.pitzer.edu/academics/faculty/zuckerman/Zuckerman_on_Atheism.pdf|title=Atheism, Secularity, and Well-Being: How the Findings of Social Science Counter Negative Stereotypes and Assumptions|first=Phil|last=Zuckerman|journal=Sociology Compass|volume=3|issue=6|year=2009|pages=949–971|doi=10.1111/j.1751-9020.2009.00247.x|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141228104545/http://www.pitzer.edu/academics/faculty/zuckerman/Zuckerman_on_Atheism.pdf|archivedate=28 December 2014 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
Prominent atheists and atheist groups have said that discrimination against atheists is illustrated by a statement reportedly made by [[George H. W. Bush]] during a public press conference just after announcing his candidacy for the presidency in 1987.<ref name="dawkins" /><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.atheistsforhumanrights.org/mugged.htm |title = Your money and/or your life: mugged by the mythmakers |publisher = Atheists For Human Rights |accessdate = 2009-02-27 |last = Castle |first = Marie Alena |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090119230706/http://atheistsforhumanrights.org/mugged.htm |archive-date = 19 January 2009 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.positiveatheism.org/writ/ghwbush.htm |title = George H. Bush: "Atheists Neither Citizens Nor Patriots |publisher = American Atheists |accessdate = 2009-02-27 |last = O'Hair |first = Madalyn |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090228202939/http://positiveatheism.org/writ/ghwbush.htm |archivedate = 28 February 2009 |df = dmy }} </ref><ref name="saxon">{{cite news|title= Godless in Tucson; Atheists—the least-trusted group in America—speak out|last=Burns|first=Saxon|date=30 November 2006 |work=Tucson Weekly|url=http://www.tucsonweekly.com/gbase/Currents/Content?oid=89764|accessdate=2009-02-27}}</ref> When asked by journalist Robert Sherman about the equal citizenship and patriotism of American atheists, Sherman reported that Bush answered, "No, I don't know that atheists should be regarded as citizens, nor should they be regarded as patriotic. George H. W. Bush's son, [[George W. Bush]], responded to a question about the role of faith in his presidency during a November 3, 2004 press conference, "I will be your president regardless of your faith. And I don't expect you to agree with me, necessarily, on religion. As a matter of fact, no president should ever try to impose religion on our society. The great – the great tradition of America is one where people can worship the – the way they want to worship. And if they choose not to worship, they're just as patriotic as your neighbor."<ref> {{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/11/04/politics/04BUSHTRANS.html?pagewanted=4 |title= Transcript of President Bush's News Conference |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=2012-01-17 |date=4 November 2004 }} </ref> {{anchor|seven}}
On December 16, 2016, President Barack Obama signed H.R. 1150, an amendment to the [[Frank R. Wolf International Religious Freedom Act]]. It includes protections for "non-theistic beliefs, as well as the right not to profess or practice any religion at all."<ref name=Emery >{{Citation |last=Emery |first=David |date=December 20, 2016 |title=Obama Signs Law Protecting Atheists from Religious Persecution |publisher=[[Snopes.com]] |url=http://www.snopes.com/2016/12/21/obama-signs-law-protecting-atheists/ |accessdate=December 23, 2016 }}</ref>
=====Atheists eligible to hold office=====
''[[Torcaso v. Watkins]]'', {{ussc|367|488|1961}} was a [[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]] case in which the court reaffirmed that the [[United States Constitution]] prohibits States and the Federal Government from [[Religious qualifications for public office in the United States|requiring any kind of religious test for public office]]; the specific case with Torcaso was regarding his being an atheist and his work as a [[notary public]].
The constitutions of seven "[[Bible Belt]]" U.S. states ban atheists from holding public office. However, these laws are unenforceable due to conflicting with the First Amendment and Article VI of the United States Constitution:<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/constitution/articlevi|title=Article VI|publisher=Legal Information Institute}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/constitution/first_amendment|title=U.S. Constitution – First Amendment|publisher=Legal Information Institute}}</ref>
;Arkansas :Article 19, Section 1<br />"No person who denies the being of a God shall hold any office in the civil departments of this State, nor be competent to testify as a witness in any Court."<ref>{{cite book|title=Constitution of the State of Arkansas|url=http://www.arkleg.state.ar.us/assembly/Summary/ArkansasConstitution1874.pdf|publisher=Arkansas State Legislature|location=Little Rock, AR|accessdate=17 July 2012}}</ref> ;Maryland :Article 37<br />"That no religious test ought ever to be required as a qualification for any office of profit or trust in this State, other than a declaration of belief in the existence of God; nor shall the Legislature prescribe any other oath of office than the oath prescribed by this Constitution."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msa.md.gov/msa/mdmanual/43const/html/00dec.html|title=Constitution of Maryland|date=June 10, 2011|publisher=Maryland State Archives|accessdate=17 July 2012|location=Annapolis, MD}}</ref> ;Mississippi :Article 14, Section 265<br />"No person who denies the existence of a Supreme Being shall hold any office in this state."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sos.ms.gov/links/ed_pubs/pubs/Mississippi_Constitution.pdf |title=Constitution of the State of Mississippi |publisher=Secretary of State, State of Mississippi |page=117 |accessdate=17 July 2012 |location=Jackson, MS |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150421040130/http://www.sos.ms.gov/links/ed_pubs/pubs/Mississippi_Constitution.pdf |archivedate=21 April 2015 }}</ref> ;North Carolina :Article 6, Section 8<br />"The following persons shall be disqualified for office: First, any person who shall deny the being of Almighty God."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncga.state.nc.us/legislation/constitution/ncconstitution.html|title=North Carolina State Constitution Article VI Section 8.|accessdate=2012-12-28}}</ref> ;South Carolina :Article 17, Section 4<br />"No person who denies the existence of a Supreme Being shall hold any office under this Constitution."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scstatehouse.gov/scconstitution/a17.php|title=South Carolina Constitution Article 17 Section 4.|accessdate=2012-06-18|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120602034511/http://www.scstatehouse.gov/scconstitution/a17.php|archivedate=2 June 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> ;Tennessee :Article 9, Section 2<br />"No person who denies the being of God, or a future state of rewards and punishments, shall hold any office in the civil department of this state."<ref>{{cite book|title=Tennessee Blue Book 2011-2012|url=http://www.tn.gov/sos/bluebook/11-12/TS5_TNFoundingDocs.pdf|publisher=Secretary of State, State of Tennessee|location=Nashville, TN|chapter=Article IX, Disqualifications|access-date=17 July 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120714110000/http://tn.gov/sos/bluebook/11-12/TS5_TNFoundingDocs.pdf|archive-date=14 July 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> ;Texas :Article 1, Section 4<br />"No religious test shall ever be required as a qualification to any office, or public trust, in this State; nor shall any one be excluded from holding office on account of his religious sentiments, provided he acknowledge the existence of a Supreme Being."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.statutes.legis.state.tx.us/Docs/CN/htm/CN.1.htm|title=Texas Constitution, Article 1, Section 4.|accessdate=2012-06-18}}</ref>
An eighth state constitution affords special protection to theists. ;Pennsylvania :Article 1, Section 4<br />"No person who acknowledges the being of a God and a future state of rewards and punishments shall, on account of his religious sentiments, be disqualified to hold any office or place of trust or profit under this Commonwealth."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://sites.state.pa.us/PA_Constitution.html | title=Pennsylvania Constitution, Article 1, Section 4.| accessdate=2012-10-10}}</ref>
===Muslim-majority countries=== {{see also|Persecution of atheists in the Middle East|Islam and atheism|Apostasy in Islam}} Atheists, and those accused of defection from the official religion, may be subject to discrimination and persecution in many Muslim-majority countries.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/12/10/us-religion-atheists-idUSBRE8B900520121210|title=Atheists around world suffer persecution, discrimination: report|author=Robert Evans|date=Dec 9, 2012|newspaper=Reuters}}</ref> According to the [[International Humanist and Ethical Union]], compared to other nations, "unbelievers... in Islamic countries face the most severe – sometimes brutal – treatment".<ref name= "iheu report">{{cite web|url=http://iheu.org/story/you-can-be-put-death-atheism-13-countries-around-world|title=International Humanist and Ethical Union - You can be put to death for atheism in 13 countries around the world|publisher=|accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> Atheists and religious skeptics can be executed in at least fourteen nations: [[Afghanistan]], [[Iran]], [[Malaysia]], [[Maldives]], [[Mauritania]], [[Nigeria]], [[Pakistan]], [[Qatar]], [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Somalia]], [[Sudan]], [[Libya]], the [[United Arab Emirates]] and [[Yemen]].<ref name=reuters131210>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/12/10/us-religion-atheists-idUSBRE9B900G20131210|title=Atheists face death in 13 countries, global discrimination: study|author=Robert Evans|date=December 9, 2013|publisher=[[Reuters]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url = http://freethoughtreport.com/download-the-report/|title = International Humanist and Ethical Union (IHEU),|date = 2015}}</ref>
According to popular interpretations of Islam, Muslims are not free to change religion or become an atheist: denying Islam and thus becoming an [[apostasy|apostate]] is traditionally punished by death for men and by life imprisonment for women. The death penalty for apostasy is apparent in a range of Islamic states including: Iran,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iran/3179465/Hanged-for-being-a-Christian-in-Iran.html|title=Hanged for being a Christian in Iran|date=11 October 2008|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/31/uk-iran-execution-apostasy-idUKTRE70U41D20110131|title=Iran hangs man convicted of apostasy|publisher=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> Egypt,<ref name="Supporting Islam's apostates">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2007/sep/17/supportingislamsapostates,|title="Supporting Islam's apostates"|publisher=}}</ref> Pakistan,<ref name="Supporting Islam's apostates"/> Somalia,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7833621.stm|title=Somali executed for 'apostasy'|work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> United Arab Emirates,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://freedomcenterstudents.org/2010/05/crimes-punishable-by-death-in-the-uae-include-apostasy/|title=Crimes punishable by death in the UAE include…apostasy - Freedom Center Students|publisher=|accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> Qatar,<ref name=barnabasfund>{{cite web|url=http://www.barnabasfund.org/news/archives/article.php?ID_news_items=295|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070709045248/http://www.barnabasfund.org/news/archives/article.php?ID_news_items=295|dead-url=yes|archive-date=9 July 2007|title=/news/archives/article.php|publisher=|accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> Yemen<ref name=barnabasfund/> and Saudi Arabia.<ref name="Supporting Islam's apostates"/> Although there have been no recently reported executions in Saudi Arabia,<ref>[http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/World/20060327/muslims_conversion_060327/ CTV news, "'Apostasy' laws widespread in Muslim world"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120120041820/http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/World/20060327/muslims_conversion_060327/ |date=20 January 2012 }}, quote: "Islamic Shariah law considers conversion to any religion apostasy and most Muslim scholars agree the punishment is death. Saudi Arabia considers Shariah the law of the land, though there have been no reported cases of executions of converts from Islam in recent memory."</ref> a judge in Saudi Arabia has recently recommended that imprisoned blogger [[Raif Badawi]] go before a high court on a charge of apostasy, which would carry the death penalty upon conviction.<ref>{{cite news |last=Abdelaziz |first=Salma |date=2013-12-26 |title=Wife: Saudi blogger recommended for apostasy trial |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/12/25/world/meast/saudi-blogger-death-sentence/index.html |publisher=Cnn.com |accessdate=2014-01-08}}</ref> While a death sentence is rare, it is common for atheists to be charged with blasphemy or inciting hatred.<ref name=Econ20121124>{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/news/international/21567059-ex-muslim-atheists-are-becoming-more-outspoken-tolerance-still-rare-no-god-not|title=No God, not even Allah: Ex-Muslim atheists are becoming more outspoken, but tolerance is still rare|date=Nov 24, 2012|newspaper=Economist}}</ref> New "[[Arab Spring]]" regimes in Tunisia and Egypt have jailed several outspoken atheists.<ref name=Econ20121124 />
Since an apostate can be considered a Muslim whose beliefs cast doubt on the Divine, and/or [[Qur'an]], claims of atheism and [[apostasy]] have been made against Muslim scholars and political opponents throughout history.<ref name="kamrava">{{cite book|last=Kamrava|first=Mehran|title=The new voices of Islam: reforming politics and modernity : a reader |publisher=I.B.Tauris|year=2006|pages=123–24|isbn=978-1-84511-275-2|url=https://books.google.com/?id=wTYJv7mwCoIC&pg=PA123}}</ref><ref name="isbn90-411-1105-0">{{cite book| last = Hamad|first= Ahmad| chapter= Legal plurality and legitimation of human rights abuses | editor1 = Al-Zwaini, Laila|editor2= Baudouin Dupret |editor3= Berger, Maurits | title = Legal pluralism in the Arab world | publisher = Kluwer Law International | location = The Hague | year = 1999 | page = 221 | isbn = 90-411-1105-0 | oclc = | url = https://books.google.com/?id=VAcOB1eMa5QC&pg=PA221 }}</ref><ref name="apost">{{cite book | author = Zaki Badawi, M.A.| chapter= Islam | title = Encyclopedia of religious freedom | editor= Cookson, Catharine| publisher = Routledge | location = New York | year = 2003 | pages = 204–8| isbn = 0-415-94181-4 | oclc = | url = https://books.google.com/?id=R0PrjC1Ar7gC&pg=PA206 }}</ref> Both fundamentalists and moderates agree that "blasphemers will not be forgiven" although they disagree on the severity of an appropriate punishment.<ref name=Econ20121124/> In northwestern [[Syria]] in 2013 during the [[Syrian Civil War]], [[Islamic extremism|jihadists]] beheaded and defaced a sculpture of [[Al-Maʿarri]] (973–1058 CE), one of several outspoken Arab and Persian atheist intellectuals who lived and taught during the [[Islamic Golden Age]].<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/12/us-syria-crisis-statue-idUSBRE91B13420130212 ''Syria Violence Claims Head of Ancient Arab Poet'']. Reuters, 12 Feb. 2013. Accessed 15 Dec. 2013.</ref><ref>[http://observers.france24.com/content/20130214-jihadists-behead-statue-syrian-poet-abul-ala-al-maari ''Jihadists Behead Statue of Syrian Poet Abul Ala Al-Maari'']. The Observers, France 24. 14 Feb. 2013. Accessed 15 Dec. 2013.</ref>
[[Jordan]] requires atheists to associate themselves with a recognized religion for official identification purposes.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://2001-2009.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2008/108485.htm |title=International Religious Freedom Report 2008-Jordan |publisher= US of Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor |accessdate=2009-03-14 }} </ref> In [[Egypt]], intellectuals suspected of holding atheistic beliefs have been prosecuted by judicial and religious authorities. Novelist Alaa Hamad was convicted of publishing a book that contained atheistic ideas and apostasy that were considered to threaten national unity and social peace.<ref name="boyle">{{cite book|last=Boyle|first=Kevin|author2=Sheen, Juliet |title=Freedom of Religion and Belief: A World Report |publisher=Routledge |year=1997|page=30|isbn=978-0-415-15978-4|url=https://books.google.com/?id=MFUZkWWgOtMC&pg=RA1-PA30}}</ref><ref name="al">{{cite book | author =Al-Boray, Nagad | chapter= Egypt| title = Secrecy and Liberty: National Security, Freedom of Expression and Access to Information (International Studies in Human Rights) | publisher = Springer | location = Berlin | year = 1999 | isbn = 90-411-1191-3 | oclc = | url = https://books.google.com/?id=72IynQKXt3sC&pg=PA251}}</ref>
====Algeria==== The study of Islam is a requirement in public and private schools for every Algerian child, irrespective of their religion.
Atheist or agnostic men are prohibited from marrying Muslim women ([[Algerian Family Code]] I.II.31).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lexalgeria.net/droitdelafamille.htm |title=de beste bron van informatie over Lexalgeria. Deze website is te koop! |publisher=lexalgeria.net |date=2 January 2011 |accessdate=4 December 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040623101746/http://www.lexalgeria.net/droitdelafamille.htm|archivedate=23 June 2004 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> A marriage is legally nullified by the apostasy of the husband (presumably from Islam, although this is not specified; Family Code I.III.33). Atheists and agnostics cannot inherit (Family Code III.I.138).
====Bangladesh==== {{main|Attacks on secularists in Bangladesh}} {{See also|Persecution of atheists in Bangladesh|Religion in Bangladesh#Atheism|Freedom of religion in Bangladesh#Persecution of atheists}} Several Bangladeshi atheists have been assassinated, and a "hit list" exists issued by the Bangladeshi Islamic extremist organization, the ''[[Ansarullah Bangla Team]]''. Activist atheist bloggers are leaving Bangladesh under threat of assassination.<ref name=Bengali_assassination_of_atheists>{{Cite news |first1 = Staff |last1 = Writer |title = ‘You’ll be next’: Bangladeshi blogger gets death threat on Facebook |publisher = The times of India |date = May 30, 2015 |location = Kolkata |newspaper = Times of India |url = http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/south-asia/Youll-be-next-Bangladeshi-blogger-gets-death-threat-on-Facebook/articleshow/47477859.cms}}</ref>
====Indonesia==== {{Further|Anti-atheist sentiment in Indonesia}} {{See also|Religion in Indonesia#Atheism|Islam in Indonesia#Religious freedom}} Atheists in [[Indonesia]] experience official discrimination in the context of registration of births and marriages, and the issuance of identity cards.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90137.htm |title=International Religious Freedom Report 2007-Indonesia |publisher= US of Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor |accessdate=2009-03-14 }}</ref> In 2012, Indonesian atheist [[Alexander Aan]] was beaten by a mob, lost his job as a civil servant and was sentenced to two and a half years in jail for expressing his views online.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/archive/amnesty-calls-for-release-of-jailed-indonesian-atheist/524453/|title=Amnesty Calls for Release of Jailed Indonesian Atheist|work=Jakarta Globe|date= 15 June 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921223626/http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/archive/amnesty-calls-for-release-of-jailed-indonesian-atheist/524453/|archivedate=21 September 2013|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/may/03/indonesia-atheists-religious-freedom-aan|title=Indonesia's atheists face battle for religious freedom|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=3 May 2012}}</ref>
=====Indonesian genocide===== {{main article|Indonesian mass killings of 1965–1966}} Jess Melvin argues that atheists were victims of [[genocide]] under the legal definition during the 1965-66 [[Indonesian genocide|Anti-PKI extermination campaign]] (PKI were the [[Communist Party of Indonesia]]) as the Indonesian army proscribed the destruction of "atheist" and "unbelievers" collectively for their association with [[communism]], and according to Matthew Lippmann and David Nersessian [[atheists]] are covered as a protected group in the [[genocide convention]] under "religious group."<ref> Melvin, Jess (2017). "Mechanics of Mass Murder: A case for Understanding the Indonesian Killings as Genocide. [[Journal of Genocide Research]] 19 (4): 487-511. doi:10. 1080/14623528.2017.1393942.</ref>
====Iran==== {{Further|Irreligion in Iran}} Since atheism is not a belief or religion, non-believers are not given legal status in Iran. Declaration of faith in Islam, Christianity, Judaism or Zoroastrianism is required to avail of certain rights such as applying for entrance to university,<ref name="fidh.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.fidh.org/IMG/pdf/ir0108a.pdf|title=Discrimination against religious minorities in IRAN|date=August 2003|work=Fédération Internationale des Ligues des Droits de l`Homme and the Ligue de Défense des Droits de l'Homme en Iran|accessdate=2009-03-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Iranian Atheists Association: Issues|publisher= Iranian Atheists Association|url= https://iranianatheists.org/issues-1.html|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20130924185308/https://iranianatheists.org/issues-1.html|archivedate= 24 September 2013|df= dmy-all}}</ref> or becoming a lawyer, with the position of judge reserved for Muslims only.<ref> {{cite web |url = https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/mde13/045/2001/en/ |title = Iran: A legal system that fails to protect freedom of expression and association |publisher = Amnesty International |accessdate = 2009-03-14 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> The Penal Code is also based upon the religious affiliation of the victim and perpetrator, with the punishment oftentimes more severe on non-Muslims.<ref name="fidh.org"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Apostasy in the Islamic Republic of Iran|url=http://www.iranhrdc.org/english/publications/reports/1000000512-apostasy-in-the-islamic-republic-of-iran.html|website=Iranian Human Rights Documentation Center|accessdate=22 June 2015}}</ref> Numerous writers, thinkers and philanthropists have been accused of apostasy and sentenced to death for questioning the prevailing interpretation of Islam in Iran.<ref>{{cite web|title=Iranian Writer Sentenced to Death for Apostasy|url=http://www.iranhrdc.org/english/news/inside-iran/1000000588-iranian-writer-sentenced-to-death-for-apostasy.html|website=Iran Human Rights Documentation Center|accessdate=22 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Human Rights Questions: Human Rights Situations and Reports of Special Rapporteurs and Representatives -- Situation of Human Rights in the Islamic Republic of Iran|url=http://www.iranhrdc.org/english/human-rights-documents/aadel-collection/11756-human-rights-questions-human-rights-situations-and-reports-of-special-rapporteurs-and-representatives-situation-of-human-rights-in-the-islamic-republic-of-iran.html|website=Iran Human Rights Documentation Center|accessdate=22 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Witness Statement: Mahmoud Roghani|url=http://www.iranhrdc.org/english/publications/witness-testimony/1000000543-witness-statement-of-hasan-yousefi-eshkevari.html|website=Iran Human Rights Documentation Center.|accessdate=22 June 2015}}</ref> The Iranian Atheists Association was established in 2013 to form a platform for Iranian atheists to start debates and to question the current Islamic regime's attitude towards atheists, apostasy, and human rights.<ref>{{cite news|title= Iranian Atheists Association: About Us|publisher= Iranian Atheists.org |date=|url= http://Iranianatheists.org/about-us.html}}</ref>
====Libya==== Atheism is prohibited in [[Libya]] and can come with a [[Capital punishment in Libya|death penalty]], if one is charged as an atheist.<ref name="itcadel.gov.ly">http://itcadel.gov.ly/wp-content/uploads/pdfs2013/add04-2016.pdf</ref>
In June 2013, Libya’s General National Council assembly (GNC) voted to make Islamic Sharia law the base for all legislation and for all state institutions, a decision have an impact in banking, criminal and financial law.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-libya-law-idUSBRE9B30M220131204|title=Libyan assembly votes to follow Islamic law|first=Reuters|last=Editorial|publisher=}}</ref> In February 2016, Libya’s General National Council assembly (GNC) released adecree No.20 Changing on provisions of the Libyan Penal Code.<ref name="itcadel.gov.ly"/>
====Saudi Arabia==== {{Main|Irreligion in Saudi Arabia}} Atheism is prohibited in [[Saudi Arabia]] and can come with a [[Capital punishment in Saudi Arabia|death penalty]], if one is charged as an atheist.<ref>{{cite news|title= Why Are Saudis Tearing Up the Quran? |publisher= [[Vocativ]]|date=|url= http://www.vocativ.com/world/saudi-arabia-world/blasphemy-land-two-holy-mosques/|accessdate=2014-04-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Atheists Classified As Terrorists Under New Saudi Arabian Laws |publisher= [[Huffington Post]]|date=|url= http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2014/04/02/atheists-classified-terrorists-new-saudi-arabian-laws_n_5075129.html|accessdate=2014-03-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Saudi Arabia: A wave of atheism or a misunderstanding|publisher= [[Al Arabiya]]|date= |url= http://english.alarabiya.net/views/2012/05/23/215974.html|accessdate= 2012-11-28|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20160304043137/http://english.alarabiya.net/views/2012/05/23/215974.html|archive-date= 4 March 2016|dead-url= yes|df= dmy-all}}</ref>
In March 2014, the Saudi interior ministry issued a royal decree branding all atheists as terrorists, which defines [[terrorism]] as "calling for atheist thought in any form, or calling into question the fundamentals of the Islamic religion on which this country is based".<ref>{{cite web|author=Adam Withnall |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/saudi-arabia-declares-all-atheists-are-terrorists-in-new-law-to-crack-down-on-political-dissidents-9228389.html |title=Saudi Arabia declares all atheists are terrorists in new law to crack down on political dissidents - Middle East - World |publisher=The Independent |date=1 April 2014 |accessdate=27 December 2014}}</ref>
====Turkey==== {{Further|Irreligion in Turkey}} Although officially a [[secular state]], the vast majority of Turks are Muslim, and the state grants some special privileges to Muslims and to Islam in the media and private religious institutions. Compulsory religious instruction in [[Turkey|Turkish]] schools is also considered discriminatory towards atheists, who may not want their children to receive any religious education.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/47665e602.html|title= A Quest for Equality: Minorities in Turkey|year= 2007|publisher= Minority Rights Group International|accessdate=2009-03-14|quote=Compulsory religious instruction in schools is discriminatory not only against Alevis, as is often emphasized by the EU,195 but also against other non-Sunni Muslims and Sunni Muslims who either do not conform to the Sunni Hanefi faith or do not agree with its official version. It is also discriminatory against atheists, agnostics and secularists, who may not wish their children to receive any religious education.}}</ref> Atheists and agnostics are also not counted in the official census of the country.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}}
===India=== [[Sanal Edamaruku]], atheist and founder-president of Rationalist International, had to flee India when Catholic Secular Forum pressed charges against him under Section 295(A) of the Indian Penal Code, which penalises outraging the religious sentiments of any citizen, in 2012<ref>Shaffer, R (March–April 2013). "Blasphemy, Free Speech, and Rationalism: An Interview with Sanal Edamaruku". The Humanist. Retrieved 2013-02-23."Blasfemia, libertad de expresión, y el racionalismo: Una entrevista con Sanal Edamaruku". The Humanist/Europa Laicismo. March 2013. Retrieved 2013-02-23.</ref>. He is currently in self exile in Finland to evade arrest and indefinite jail time.<ref>Sims, Paul. "Sanal Edamaruku: an update". 18 June 2012. New Humanist Magazine. Retrieved 1 March 2014.</ref>
===Other=== [[Regular Freemasonry]] insists among other things that a volume of scripture is open in a working lodge, that every member profess belief in a Supreme Being, and that the discussion of religion is banned. [[Continental Freemasonry]] is now the general term for the "liberal" jurisdictions which have removed some, or all, of these restrictions.
"Duty to God" is a [[Scout method#Principles|principle of Scouting]] worldwide, though it is applied differently among countries.<ref name="faqs">{{cite web | year=1998 | url=http://www.faqs.org/faqs/scouting/rec.scouting.issues/section-11.html | title = What was Baden-Powell's position on God and Religion in Scouting? | publisher = Faqs | accessdate = 2006-12-03}}</ref><ref name="inquiry">{{cite web |last=Baden-Powell |first=Robert |year=1912 |url=http://www.inquiry.net/ideals/b-p/religion.htm |title=Baden-Powell on Religion |publisher=Inquiry.net |accessdate=2006-12-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061115192441/http://www.inquiry.net/ideals/b-p/religion.htm |archivedate=2006-11-15 |df= }}</ref> The [[Boy Scouts of America]] (BSA) takes a strong position, excluding atheists and [[agnostics]],<ref name="duty">{{cite web|url=http://www.bsalegal.org/dutytogo-155.htm|work=BSA Legal Issues|title=Duty to God|publisher=Boy Scouts of America|accessdate=2006-12-03|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060827022542/http://www.bsalegal.org/dutytogo-155.htm|archivedate=2006-08-27|df=}}</ref><ref name="dutytogod">{{cite web | url = http://www.bsa-discrimination.org/html/god-top.html | title = BSA and Religious Belief | publisher = BSA Discrimination.org | accessdate = 2006-10-16}}</ref> while [[Girl Scouts of the USA]] takes a more neutral position. The [[The Scout Association|United Kingdom Scout Association]] has recently published alternative promises for people of different or no religion, specifying "Atheists, Humanists and people of no specific religion", who make a promise to uphold Scouting values rather than a duty to God. [[Scouts Canada]] defines Duty to God broadly in terms of "adherence to spiritual principles" and does not require members to be part of an organized religion, but does require that they have some form of "personal spirituality".<ref name="bscfaq">{{cite web| url=http://www.scouts.ca/ca/frequently-asked-questions |title=Scouts Canada FAQ | publisher = Scouts Canada | accessdate=2010-01-04}}</ref> In other countries, especially in Europe, some Scouting organizations may be [[secularism|secularist]] or religiously neutral (such as [[Eclaireuses et Eclaireurs de France]], [[Corpo Nazionale Giovani Esploratori ed Esploratrici Italiani]] and the ''Baden-Powell Service Association'' in the United States<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bpsa-us.org/about/policies-guidelines/|title=BPSA-US Policy & Guidelines|publisher=}}</ref>).

A '''dispute mechanism''' is a structured process<ref>{{cite web|url=http://accessfacility.org/mechanisms/all |title=ACCESS Facility database of non-judicial grievance mechanisms|accessdate=2013-12-13}}</ref> that addresses disputes or grievances that arise between two or more parties engaged in business, legal, or societal relationships. Dispute mechanisms are used in [[dispute resolution]], and may incorporate [[conciliation]], [[conflict resolution]], [[mediation]], and [[negotiation]].
Otherwise known as '''grievance mechanisms''', dispute mechanisms are typical non-judicial<ref name="unglobalcompact1">{{cite web|url=http://www.unglobalcompact.org/docs/issues_doc/human_rights/Human_Rights_Working_Group/29Apr08_7_Report_of_SRSG_to_HRC.pdf |title=0812861 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2010-05-17}}</ref> in nature, meaning that they are not resolved within the court of law. According to research produced by the non-judicial grievance mechanism task force of John Ruggie, Special Representative of Business and Human Rights to the United Nations, those who design and oversee non-judicial mechanisms should acknowledge core human rights processes defined by "all core UN human rights treaties.”<ref>These principles, based on more specific guidance developed for companies, apply across non-judicial mechanisms of different kinds. See http://www.business-humanrights.org/Links/Repository/308254/ link_page_view.</ref>
Dispute mechanisms comprise a way for [[Social responsibility|socially responsible]] businesses to meet requirements of corporate responsibility-related agreements or pacts, reduce risk while capacity-building or developing internationally, and assist larger processes that create positive social change.
Dispute mechanisms are an increasingly effective tool for establishing communication channels between businesses and communities. When successful, they offer a trusted way for local peoples or communities to voice and resolve concerns related to development projects, while providing companies with transparent, effective ways to address community concerns. According to a publication by the [[Compliance Advisor/Ombudsman]] of the [[World Bank Group]], "locally-based grievance resolution mechanism(s) provide a promising avenue by offering a reliable structure and set of approaches where local people and the company can find effective solutions together."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://commdev.org/content/document/detail/2269/ |title=A Guide to Designing and Implementing Grievance Mechanisms for Development Projects |publisher=Commdev.org |date= |accessdate=2010-05-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090817075908/http://commdev.org/content/document/detail/2269/ |archivedate=2009-08-17 |df= }}</ref> Generally, it is agreed that a well-functioning grievance mechanism should:
* Provides a predictable, transparent, and credible process to all parties, resulting in outcomes that are seen as fair, effective, and lasting * Builds trust as an integral component of broader community relations activities * Enables more systematic identification of emerging issues and trends, facilitating corrective action and preemptive engagement.
==Characteristics== According to the Business and Human Rights SRSG, such mechanisms must at a minimum be: * '''Legitimate''': a mechanism must have clear, transparent and sufficiently independent governance structures to ensure that no party to a particular grievance process can interfere with the fair conduct of that process; * '''Accessible''': a mechanism must be publicized to those who may wish to access it and provide adequate assistance for aggrieved parties who may face barriers to access, including language, literacy, awareness, finance, distance, or fear of reprisal; * '''Predictable''': a mechanism must provide a clear and known procedure with a time frame for each stage and clarity on the types of process and outcome it can (and cannot) offer, as well as a means of monitoring the implementation of any outcome; * '''Equitable''': a mechanism must ensure that aggrieved parties have reasonable access to sources of information, advice and expertise necessary to engage in a grievance process on fair and equitable terms; * '''Rights-compatible''': a mechanism must ensure that its outcomes and remedies accord with internationally recognized human rights standards; * '''Transparent''': a mechanism must provide sufficient transparency of process and outcome to meet the public interest concerns at stake and should presume transparency wherever possible; non-State mechanisms in particular should be transparent about the receipt of complaints and the key elements of their outcomes.<ref name="unglobalcompact1"/>
==Types== * Industry * Company * Legislative * Government * Non-Governmental * Independent State-based * International Organization * Multi-Stakeholder
==Uses== Well-designed grievance mechanisms have multiple and sometimes divergent points of application, but are typically used by monitoring, auditing, project oversight, supply chain management, and stakeholder engagement. Grievance mechanisms can deal with most kinds of grievances (bar those raising criminal liability), including – but by no means limited to – those that reflect substantive human/labour rights concerns. As such, rights-compatible mechanisms must work to integrate human rights norms and standards into their processes and are based on principles of non-discrimination, equity, accountability, empowerment and participation.
